headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Scott, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q1 2016 earnings call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Sameer Gokhale, Head of Investor Relations, you may begin your co
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Scott, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q1 2016 earnings call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Sameer Gokhale, Head of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we will be discussing our financial results for the first quarter of 2015. This discussion may contain certain forward-looking statements about Fifth Third pertaining to our financial co
componenttext: Thank you, Scott. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we will be discussing our financial results for the first quarter of 2015. This discussion may contain certain forward-looking statements about Fifth Third pertaining to our financial condition results of operations, plans and objectives. These statements involve risks and uncertainties that could cause results to differ materially from historical performance and these statements. We've identified some of these factors in our forward-looking cautionary statement at the end of our earnings release and in other material, and we encourage you to review them. Fifth Third undertakes no obligation and would not expect to update any such forward-looking statements after the date of this call. This morning, I'm joined on the call by our President and CEO, Greg Carmichael; CFO, Tayfun Tuzun; Chief Operating Officer, Lars Anderson; Chief Risk Officer, Frank Forrest; and our Treasurer, Jimmy Leonor. Following prepared remarks by Greg and Tayfun, we will open the call up to questions. [Operator Instructions] With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sameer. And thank all of you for joining us this morning. Today, we'll report our first quarter and then come to common shareholders of $312 million in earnings per diluted share of $0.40. We have some non-core items that added $0.03 to earnings p
componenttext:
Thanks, Sameer. And thank all of you for joining us this morning. Today, we'll report our first quarter and then come to common shareholders of $312 million in earnings per diluted share of $0.40. We have some non-core items that added $0.03 to earnings per share in the quarter. Our Q1 results were solid especially we experienced on the quarter. The income levels, including capital market fees, were stronger despite market assumptions. As you know, we've been building on our capital markets capabilities for last 3 years. We're seeing our investments to pay off. When the quarter we closed on the largest deal in the history of our company. Interest income was also stronger than expected. We benefited from low deposit December rate hike and expect to continue to manage deposit rates Given the outlook for rates, we should continue to benefit from our steady and conscious strategy with respect to rate risk management. 
We remain focused on executing our defined strategies. We closed on the sale of the branch of which resulted in $8 million pretax gain. In addition, we expect to close on the sale of the branches this week. We continue to rationalize our branch network and on track to deliver $60 million annual expense savings related to these reductions. We're in this new proxy and services. Our new Express Banking product, for example, received high accolades from the CFPB. Just we launched this product in November 2015, we were able to move 55,000 new customer accounts. Our ongoing investments in digital technology continued to accelerate our growth rate in mobile banking. 
In 2015, our growth of mobile users exceeded the industry average and accelerated. The rest of our industry experienced the slow down. In the first quarter, over 70% of our deposit transactions were executed via mobile devices and 12% in the first quarter 2012. In addition, we doubled the number of check accounts that were open online from a year ago. During the quarter, we implemented retirement program. This program resulted in a $14 million one-time expense, but will generate $9 million in annual cost savings. We will continue to look for more efficient ways to operate our company. Achieving operating leverage is our top priority. We are making progress with that goal. 
Our expenses at one timers were up 2% sequentially, partly reflecting the seasonal increase in insurance. While we're investing in our company, where very focused on controlled expenses across all of our. We now believe that our expense growth in 2016 will be lower than we had originally expected, but we will find more details in an updated in his comments. 
As we shared with you in January, we are proceeding with several strategic initiatives and improved revenue growth, generating cost efficiencies and improve service quality. We remain on track to share our progress with you as the year continues to unfold. During 2015, we discussed our effots to reduce our risk exposures. As of March 31, our loans to commodity traders were down to $241 million. That's down by more than 50% from the peak. 
On energy, oil prices did rebound outflows, but the second remains distressed. Our balances was stable from the fourth quarter at $1.7 billion. As expected, we saw continued deterioration in the book. Energy NPLs were $168 million higher than the last quarter that they represent the bulk of the total NPA -- NPL increase during the quarter. The loans are moved into the NPL category were predominately reserve-based levels. As these loans are generally we do not expect this similar increase in the charge-offs. 
At the end of the first quarter, we only had $294 million in loans to higher risk oilfield services company. We have reserves of 6.2% against our total energy portfolio, and we believe reserves are more than appropriate. Our capital levels remain strong with common equity Tier 1 of 9.8%. Our earnings contributed to a tangible book value of $16.32 per share, which was up 5% from last quarter and 9% over last year. 
During the quarter, we also announced the share repurchase of $240 million or common stock, which settled on April 11. We retired approximately 14.5 million shares. With that, I'll turn over to Tayfun to discuss our first quarter operating results and our current outlook.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Let's start with the financial summary on Page 4 of the presentation. For the first quarter, we reported net income to common shareholders of $312 million or $0.40 per diluted share. There was a ne
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Let's start with the financial summary on Page 4 of the presentation. For the first quarter, we reported net income to common shareholders of $312 million or $0.40 per diluted share. There was a net benefit in the quarter of $0.03 per share resulting from the gains on the and the brand sales offset partially by the cost of the voluntary retirement program. We are pleased with the results, especially given challenging market conditions during the quarter. 
So let's move to the average balance sheet on Page 5 of the presentation. Average commercial loan balances were relatively flat sequentially, but up about 5% year-over-year. Our end of period balances were up by $1.5 billion or 3% sequentially. The decline in average balances was partly due to higher pay downs and delays in closings at the very end of last year. We experienced healthy activity in the latter half of the first quarter. Average consumer loans were down 1% from last quarter and up 1% year-over-year. 
Residential mortgage loans grew by 2% sequentially as we continue to portfolio only jumbled mortgages and ARMs and up 11% year-over-year. Indirect auto loans are down 3% from last quarter and 5% year-over-year in line with our lower origination targets and focus on improving returns in this business. The return profile of our first quarter production was one of the best in the last few years within the super prime market that we mainly focus on. 
Average investment securities increased by $317 million in the first quarter or 1% sequentially. Average core deposits decreased $1 billion from the fourth quarter. This decrease was driven by seasonally lower demand deposits partially offset by higher interest checking balances. Our liquidity coverage ratio was very strong at 118% at the end of the quarter. 
Moving to NII on Page 6 of the presentation. Taxable equivalent net interest income increased by $5 million sequentially to $909 million despite the negative day count impact. The increase was primarily driven by improvement in variable rate loan yields due to the increase in funds rate in December with deposit data remaining at low levels. Quarter-over-quarter, our earning asset yield increased by 8 basis points accompanied by a 3 basis point increase in cost of interest-bearing liabilities. These benefits were partially offset by the effect of a reduced spread stock dividend payment and continued spread compression from the mix shift to the lower yielding, higher quality credits, which we've discussed previously. 
NII also benefited from the timing of the investment in the portfolio as cash flows were invested earlier in the quarter and the late debt issuance during the quarter. Overall, we are pleased with our NII growth over last quarter and the 7% growth year-over-year. NIM improved 6 basis points to 2.91% quarter-over-quarter. 
Shifting to fees on Page 7 of the presentation. First quarter noninterest income was $637 million compared with $1.1 billion in the fourth quarter. Our fee income adjusted primarily for Vantiv-related items and the annual $31 million TRA payment in the fourth quarter was $578 million, a decrease of $14 million or 2% sequentially. 
Despite seasonal headwinds and challenging market conditions, our results were strong. Corporate banking fees of $102 million were relatively flat sequentially, and adjusted for the write-down of the residual lease in the first quarter of 2015 were up 10% year-over-year. 
As we mentioned in January, Corporate Banking fees are seasonally lower in the first quarter and overall market conditions were weak during the quarter. So our performance was strong despite the challenging backdrop. 
Mortgage banking net revenue of $78 million was up $4 million sequentially. Originations were 1.8 billion in the first quarter, with 46% of the mix consisting of purchase volume. About 75% of the originations came from the retail and direct channels and the remainder came through the correspondent channel. Gain on sale margins were up 57 basis points sequentially to 347 basis points, and net servicing asset valuation adjustments were negative $16 million similar to last quarter. Deposit service charges decreased 5% from the fourth quarter reflecting seasonal trends in consumer deposit fees and increased 1% relative to the first quarter of 2015. 
Total investment advisory revenue of $102 million was flat sequentially, mostly reflecting weaker equity market activity during the quarter. This impact was offset by seasonally higher trust tax-preparation fees. Excluding certain onetime items, our year-over-year revenue growth reached nearly 5%, a very good outcome in a challenging environment. 
Next, I would like to discuss noninterest expense on Page 8 of the presentation. Expenses were $986 million compared with $963 million in the fourth quarter. The sequential increase was partly due to seasonally higher FICA and employment insurance expense and a $14 million expense related to the voluntary early retirement program. The early retirement program was well received by our employees and approximately 160 employees participated. As a result, we expect a $9 million decrease in annual compensation expenses. As Greg said earlier, we continue to look for other similar opportunities to improve our expense run rate. I will provide an update on our expense outlook a little later. 
Turning to credit results on Slide 9. Net charge-offs were $96 million or 42 basis points in the first quarter compared to $80 million and 34 basis points in the fourth quarter of 2015 and $91 million and 41 basis points in the first quarter a year ago. The sequential increase was due to a $16 million increase in C&I net charge-offs. All of the total net charge-offs, $9 million were in energy. Nonperforming loans, excluding loans held-for-sale, increased $195 million from the previous quarter to $701 million resulting in an NPL ratio of 75 basis points. 
Commercial NPLs increased $202 million from the fourth quarter, driven by $168 million in energy NPLs. Consumer NPLs declined by $7 million sequentially. Overall credit conditions, excluding energy, remained within our expectations. Consumer credit continues to improve and commercial credit, excluding energy, is stable. Our provision was $23 million higher than the total charge-offs in the first quarter, and our reserve coverage moved up 1 basis point to 1.38% of loans and leases. It is important to note, as Greg mentioned, that an increase in energy NPLs should not necessarily translate into an increase in charge-offs of the same magnitude. This is because the majority of energy NPLs are well collateralized and consist of reserve-based loans. 
On Slide 10, we have provided a breakdown of our energy portfolio. Our energy related loans at the end of the quarter were $1.7 billion with total commitments of $4 billion. As you can see, our loans to oilfield services companies were only $294 million or 17% of our total energy loans outstanding and leaves only $170 million in and used commitments. 
We believe that we are appropriately reserved for losses in the energy portfolio based on detailed stress analysis that our teams continue to update, not only on the oilfield services portfolio, but also on our reserve-based loans. Based on detailed analysis, we believe that our energy reserves, which are currently at 6.2%, up from 4.8% at the end of last year, are adequate. Our stress case scenario over a 9 quarter period assumes that oil prices will be at $20 in 2016 and $25 in 2017.  This stress scenario would add approximately $50 million to $60 million in net charge-offs over and above our current results. 
On Slide 11, we provide a breakdown of our commercial real estate portfolio. It is important to note that our commercial real estate business today is much different than what we had precrisis. At the end of 27, 21% of our total loans and leases were in commercial real estate. Today, we are at 11% below our peer levels. 
At the end of 2007, over 40% of our nonowner occupied exposure was in land and residential developers. Today, that exposure is slightly above 4%. As you can see, our nonperforming assets continue to decrease both within the commercial mortgage and commercial construction portfolios. 
At the end of the first quarter, NPAs in our commercial mortgage portfolio is decreased to 1.84% from 2.56% a year earlier. NPAs in our commercial construction portfolio decreased to 23 basis points from 67 basis points over the same period. During the last 2 years, we significantly upgraded our credit resources in commercial mortgage and construction underwriting, which increased our focus on client selection, geographical diversity and multifactor stress analysis. 
Moving on to capital on Slide 12. Our capital levels remain strong. Our common equity Tier 1 ratio was 9.8%, an increase of 30 basis points year-over-year. At the end of the first quarter, common shares outstanding were down approximately $15 million. During the quarter, we announced and settled a common stock repurchase of $240 million and reduced the first quarter share count by 14.5 million shares. 
Now moving to outlook. The drivers of our overall outlook remain unchanged. We expect year-over-year commercial loan growth to exceed 3% and the consumer loan portfolio to decline. The decline of our consumer loan portfolio will primarily reflect lower auto loan origination, as we had previously discussed, and includes the impact of sales associated with the St. Louis and Pittsburgh transactions. 
Our interest rate outlook now has only one rate increase in June as supposed to the 2 increases that we had in our original base case. For the second quarter, we would expect relatively stable net interest income compared with the first quarter. But despite 1 late rate increase, we still expect a 2.5% to 3% increase in NII year-over-year. In our base case, we would expect to see a 3 to 4 basis point of NIM decline in the second quarter and then all relatively steady in line with our results in 2015. 
Although deposit betas are expected to remain low, our outlook assumes incremental spread compression due to our continued emphasis on originating higher quality loans. This update improves upon our January guidance, as it includes 1 less rate increase. Without a rate increase, we would expect NII grow around 2%. 
Our overall fee income growth outlook is not changing. We expect to grow our fees between 4% and 5% on the 2015 base of $2.3 billion, which excludes Vantiv share and warrant gains that we had during the year. We are lowering our year-over-year expense outlook from 4.5% to 5% to the 4 to 4.25 range. We believe that our intense focus on expense control will result in an improvement in operating efficiency compared to our January expectations. 
The quarterly run rate will increase from the first quarter levels. And this will reflect seasonality and the timing of implementation of strategic initiatives, but we will have better year-over-year yield results than originally expected. Our second quarter results will also include a one-time approximately $10 million expense as a result of retirement eligibility changes related to long-term incentive compensation. The changes will align our retirement eligibility provisions with our peer group. This is just a change in the timing of the recognition of expenses and would lower our expenses going forward. We continue to monitor our energy exposures closely. It is likely that we will see higher charge-offs in this portfolio, primarily in the oilfield services sector. Given the relatively modest size of our exposure, future credit losses should be manageable. Credit losses ex energy should remain in the range with some potential variability quarter-to-quarter due to the historically low level of current charge-offs. 
With that, let me open the call for questions.

You don't expect to see a lot more necessarily on the energy losses, but can you just flush out your confidence is seeing the underneath if you could just parse out the portfolios what you're expecting in kind of commercial ex energy and on the consumer side?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good question. As we reported nonperforming assets are up in the quarter, almost all of that was energy related, 90-plus percent is energy related. tied to reserve-based lending loans, 7 loans, we feel very confident at this point that those loans are pro
componenttext: Good question. As we reported nonperforming assets are up in the quarter, almost all of that was energy related, 90-plus percent is energy related. tied to reserve-based lending loans, 7 loans, we feel very confident at this point that those loans are protected by the risk adjustment collateral coverage that we have in place. All borrowers in this segment that are on NPL that were just moved are current and that's important. The regulators, you probably heard on earnings call taken a much quicker view on how they are classifying these loans from the accounting perspective. They are looking to cover both the first and the second lien positions on these companies. In our case, we have a super secured first-lien position, and we belong to a very detailed portfolio analysis bottoms up of all of our energy book to ensure that they're from a borrowing perspective, we're well secured. So NPLs are up; however, it's in the segment that's very well protected on a collateral position, but historically, they're based on a current outlook. We could see additional deterioration from an energy perspective in NPL given that in the future is slightly indicated, but we are not changing our outlook on overall credit losses. Beyond that, when you look at the rest of the portfolio now again we talked this morning about commercial real estate, we feel very good about that performance is holding up us very well. We have very little exposure in commercial real estate and the energy state. We have 4 multifamily credits that are in Houston, 2 of which are stabilized, the other 2 are performing under construction according to terms that we set. And we have some exposure in Denver from commercial real estate perspective, but that market is held up very well being in an energy sector. So the overall commercial real estate at this point is performing to our expectations. Our middle market book is performing very well. We're showing very strong performance in our 4 markets. We're are not concerned there. Our leverage book is stable. We have some lumpiness quarter-to-quarter and leverage performing to our expectations as well. I hope that was responsive to your question.

componenttext: So in terms of the spreads, the spreads this quarter were a good, 25, 30 basis points above what we've seen over the past number of quarters. But I just want to remind you that, that was a very deliberate decision on our part to lower our annual originations to roughly $3 billion from $5 billion, which enables us to focus on profitability rather than volume. And our auto business is a national business that has not changed. The geographic distribution of originations is roughly about the same except for what Frank mentioned earlier. The spreads have lightened. The credit quality remains the same. So we're getting more return on the same type of capital allocation loans that we're originating.

componenttext: Yes. Right now, you saw on our book at the beginning of the quarter, January, February, we reinvested some cash flows, because we saw a little bit better entry points there. So frankly, if rates were to stay these pretty low levels, you could expect from us just to reinvest cash flows, because the entry points don't look real good. But if rates were to have a little bit of a sell off here and present more opportunity and you would expect our investment portfolio to grow in line with our asset. But I don't think you will see a lot of moment in the book one way or the other throughout 2016. Yes, remember, when were building for LCR, Matt, in the last 2 years, there was quite a bit more movement in the size of the portfolio, but looking out now, it's going going to be steadier direction.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about operating leverage. You said, operating leverage is a priority. But then, we see expenses up in the first quarter, the efficiency ratio got worse quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year. Your expense guidance is lower than befor
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about operating leverage. You said, operating leverage is a priority. But then, we see expenses up in the first quarter, the efficiency ratio got worse quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year. Your expense guidance is lower than before, but it's still over 4%. And you had closed, I guess, 2/3 of your 100 targeted branches as of last quarter. So I'm just seeing a disconnect between some of the words. That's a priority, you're closing branches and result expenses to growing faster than revenue. So I guess, my question is, why do you still have expense growth over 4% in an revenue environment that seems pretty soft? And when we'll see benefits of those branch closings?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Greg. Thanks for the question. First off, we are focused on once again continue to rationalize all of our expenses. The branch closures that we announced last year, which become we've already sold St. Louis. We closed Pittburg this week. We expect
componenttext: This is Greg. Thanks for the question. First off, we are focused on once again continue to rationalize all of our expenses. The branch closures that we announced last year, which become we've already sold St. Louis. We closed Pittburg this week. We expect to exercise by the middle of this year, and we're still on target for that $60 million improvement, annualized improvement on the branches. We also, as I had mentioned before, we offered early retirement program. We are very focused on expense but we're also focused on making the strategic investments that we have to make going forward that we hope and we anticipate we continue to drive revenue, improve our operating efficiencies, improve our service quality. We're going to make those investments, feel like that this is at the best price points sharpening the pencil, on how we spend that line to make sure that we get the return that we're looking for. We're very much focused on execution of those initiatives and driving to the outcomes. So going forward, we're guided lower on expenses that we initially anticipated for this year, albeit still at 4%. We need to be lower than that obviously. We need to create positive operating leverage and that's what we're focused on. And hopefully, as we go into this year, we'll turn to positive operating leverage.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Mike, remember, first quarter has compared to fourth quarter $25 million, $26 million higher jus in 2 line items, which is spike and underemployed insurance. So now as there is -- first quarter typically is going to be a higher efficiency ratio q
componenttext: Yes. And Mike, remember, first quarter has compared to fourth quarter $25 million, $26 million higher jus in 2 line items, which is spike and underemployed insurance. So now as there is -- first quarter typically is going to be a higher efficiency ratio quarter compared to Q4. But as Greg said and he's been talking about for a couple of quarters now, there's a quite of focus on taking out expenses from operations so that we can reinvest back in company. So our outlook -- we believe that we'll do better than what we told you in January.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Just one follow-up. Greg, I'm just curious about your style. I mean, as a new CEO, you started in the position and expenses are still growing faster than many of your peers. On the one hand, you wind up with negative operating leverage. A
componenttext: That's helpful. Just one follow-up. Greg, I'm just curious about your style. I mean, as a new CEO, you started in the position and expenses are still growing faster than many of your peers. On the one hand, you wind up with negative operating leverage. A year or 2 from now, we're all going to be saying, wow you shouldn't have not grown expenses that quickly. On the other hand, as some of your investments pay off then we're going to say, wow, this was really forward-looking on your behalf. So can you talk about your style in terms of this spending for future gains, the risk and the opportunities as you think about it in your mind?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike. First off, as I mentioned before, we have to make the investments to reposition the bank for the realities that we're operating in. We're going to be in slower rate environment we believe for some period of time. We got to focus on generating qualit
componenttext: Mike. First off, as I mentioned before, we have to make the investments to reposition the bank for the realities that we're operating in. We're going to be in slower rate environment we believe for some period of time. We got to focus on generating quality revenues with the right partnerships. We also have to focus on making sure that we have the efficiencies in our organization. If you go back and look at our operation cost, we're running our operation -- central operations less than we did in 2007 at much higher volume rate we were in 2007. We have a good history of managing expenses in this organization, and we'll continue that history going forward. But we have to invest the platform of our infrastructure, which we're doing and we'll get paid well for that. We're pruning back and leaning back our distribution channels as we mentioned before around branches. We're moving to digital capabilities for our customers, which will reduce our back-office cost, replatforming our retail platform, our mortgage platform, which be specifically more efficient going forward. We're going to get paid for those investments. So it's not lost upon me at the end of the day that we're making commitments. We've got to get the return on these commitments to the bottom line of the company and that's what we're focused on. We mentioned that and I mentioned before that this year is a transformational year to make those investments, but we're going to get paid for. So my style was this, is execution, getting it done and making commitments the made to the organization, our shareholders and our investors. And we're going to do just that. So that's we're focused on.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Winter from Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Winter from Sterne Agee.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: I'm just curious, how far through our you in terms of the mix shift to higher quality loans. And then secondly, with this mix shift, how do you think about to a cycle where your net charge-offs would be in a range versus historically?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's difficult to exactly where we are in terms of the derisking or repositioning of our balance sheet and part from that is that we have a changing economic environment, interest rate environment, economic environment. But I would tell you that w
componenttext: Yes, so it's difficult to exactly where we are in terms of the derisking or repositioning of our balance sheet and part from that is that we have a changing economic environment, interest rate environment, economic environment. But I would tell you that we continue to stay focused on it every single day. We're reallocating our resources to the businesses that best fit not just our risk appetite, but also produce the best returns for our shareholders over a long period of time. One of the keys here is not just to course to achieve the highest returns, but also position this balance sheet in our loan portfolio so that will outperform through the future cycles, which I think leads to the second part of your question, which Frank may want to have a comment on.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your question regarding loss. I mean, our normal rage is 30 to 50 basis points of loss. We performed that number over the last several years. Now we have some lumpiness quarter-to-quarter. But if you look at year-over-year performance, we stay within that
componenttext: Your question regarding loss. I mean, our normal rage is 30 to 50 basis points of loss. We performed that number over the last several years. Now we have some lumpiness quarter-to-quarter. But if you look at year-over-year performance, we stay within that range and that's where we expect to be this year. As said, we are really and focused on managing credit really well through the cycles. And so we are looking at investing in businesses that we believe will do that. We're growing our asset -- our asset-based lending business. We're growing our leasing business, but we're pulling back a bit on our leverage business. Those are all conscious decisions to ensure we have the appropriate risk and return in balance that will provide good returns and consistent performance through any cycle as we go forward.

componenttext: Well, I think, also just on an absolute basis, yes, everything else being equal. But if the environment changes and we, sort of, get to the other side of this credit cycle, it is our expectation and believe that by doing what we're doing by derisking the business, our credit performance relative to the industry should be better. That doesn't necessarily mean that at absolute level, it will stay relative to the credit cycles, we will do better.

And we'll continue to monetize that position over time.

componenttext: We continue to look at once again ways that we can continue to be a better partner in net value in our business. So when we think about our payments area, we support obviously corporate strategy verticals like retail, healthcare and so forth. So looking for opportunities in those sectors, we made a small investment in the company called We've just made a come investment in another company called and that just recently announced. So those are type of the things I'm looking for. In addition to that, we're also looking for opportunities in the wealth management sector, insurance opportunities. They may make sense for us going forward as we continue to build out our capabilities in those sectors. So we're interested in where those opportunities lie one again for the right value proposition for right long-term value for our shareholders. We're considering that. On the bank side of house, as I mentioned in prior discussions, we're really focused on opportunities to be more relevant in the markets that we're in. We can continue to be build out a quality franchise in higher growth markets like the Tennessee, Chicago markets where we're interested in when one of those opportunities materialized and makes sense for our shareholders at the right price, the right value proposition. We're continue to consider those also.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Scott, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q1 2016 earnings call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Sameer Gokhale, Head of Investor Relations, you may begin your co
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Scott, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q1 2016 earnings call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Sameer Gokhale, Head of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we will be discussing our financial results for the first quarter of 2016. This discussion may contain certain forward-looking statements about Fifth Third pertaining to our financial co
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we will be discussing our financial results for the first quarter of 2016. This discussion may contain certain forward-looking statements about Fifth Third pertaining to our financial condition, results of operations, plans and objectives. These statements involve risks and uncertainties that could cause results to differ materially from historical performance and these statements. We've identified some of these factors in our forward-looking cautionary statement at the end of our earnings release and in other materials, and we encourage you to review them. Fifth Third undertakes no obligation and would not expect to update any such forward-looking statements after the date of this call. 
This morning, I'm joined on the call by our President and CEO, Greg Carmichael; CFO, Tayfun Tuzun; Chief Operating Officer, Lars Anderson; Chief Risk Officer, Frank Forrest; and our Treasurer, Jamie Leonard. 
Following prepared remarks by Greg and Tayfun, we will open the call up to questions. [Operator Instructions] With that, I'll turn the call over to Greg.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sameer, and thank all of you for joining us this morning. Today, we report our first quarter and then come to common shareholders of $312 million in earnings per diluted share of $0.40. We had some noncore items that added $0.03 to earnings per sh
componenttext:
Thanks, Sameer, and thank all of you for joining us this morning. Today, we report our first quarter and then come to common shareholders of $312 million in earnings per diluted share of $0.40. We had some noncore items that added $0.03 to earnings per share in the quarter. Our Q1 results were solid, especially concerned of market volatility we experienced during the quarter. The income levels, including capital market fees, were stronger despite market disruptions. As you know, we've been building out our capital markets capabilities for last few years. We're seeing our investments pay off. During the quarter we closed on the largest M&A deal in the history of our company. Net interest income was also stronger than expected. We benefited from low deposit betas, following the December rate hike and expect to continue to manage deposit rates tightly. Given the outlook for rates, we should continue to benefit from our steady and conscious strategy with respect to rate risk management.
We remain focused on executing our defined strategies. We closed on the sale of the branch of the St. Louis, which resulted in $8 million pretax gain. In addition, we expect to close on the sale of the Pittsburgh branch this week. We continue to rationalize our branch network and on track to deliver $60 million annual expense savings related to these reductions.
We're introducing new products and services. Our new Express Banking product, for example, received high accolades directly from the CFPB. Since we launched this product in November 2015, we've added [ph] more than 65,000 new customer accounts. Our ongoing investments in digital technology continue to accelerate our growth rate in mobile banking.
In 2015, the growth of mobile users exceeded the industry average and then accelerated, while the rest of our industry experienced the slow down. In the first quarter, over 70% of our deposit transactions were executed via mobile devices compared with 12% in the first quarter of 2012. In addition, we doubled the number of check accounts that were open online from a year ago. During the quarter, we implemented an early retirement program. This program resulted in a $14 million onetime expense, but will generate $9 million in annual cost savings. We will continue to look for more efficient ways to operate our company. Achieving operating leverage is our top priority. We are making progress with that goal.
Our expenses net of one timers were up 2% sequentially, partly reflecting the seasonal increase in FICA and employment insurance. While we're investing in our company, we are very focused on controlling expenses across all of our operations. We now believe that our expense growth in 2016 will be lower than we had originally expected. Tuzun will provide more details in an update in our outlook in his comments. 
As we shared with you in January, we are proceeding with several strategic initiatives to improve revenue growth, generate cost efficiencies and to improve service quality. We'll remain on track in attempt to share progress with you as the year continues to unfold. During 2015, we discussed our efforts to reduce our risk exposures. As of March 31, our loans to commodity traders were down to $241 million. That's down by more than 50% from the peak.
On energy, oil prices did rebound outflows, but the second remains distressed. Our balances were stable from the fourth quarter at $1.7 billion. As expected, we saw continued deterioration in the book. Energy NPLs were $168 million higher than the last quarter, but they represent the bulk of the total NPA -- NPL increase during the quarter. The loans are moved into the NPL category predominately reserve-based levels. As these loans are generally [indiscernible], we did not expect a similar increase in net charge-offs.
At the end of the first quarter, we only had $294 million in loans to the higher-risk oilfield services companies. We have reserves of 6.2% against our total energy portfolio, and we believe these reserves are more than appropriate. Our capital levels remained strong with common equity Tier 1 of 9.8%. Our earnings contributed to a tangible book value of $16.32 per share, which was up 5% from last quarter and 9% over last year.
During the quarter, we also announced the share repurchase of $240 million of our common stock, which settled on April 11. We retired approximately 14.5 million shares. 
With that, I'll turn over to Tayfun to discuss our first quarter operating results and our current outlook.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Let's start with the financial summary on Page 4 of the presentation. For the first quarter, we reported net income to common shareholders of $312 million or $0.40 per diluted share. There was a ne
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Let's start with the financial summary on Page 4 of the presentation. For the first quarter, we reported net income to common shareholders of $312 million or $0.40 per diluted share. There was a net benefit in the quarter of $0.03 per share, resulting from the gains on the Vantiv warrants and branch sales, offset partially by the cost of the voluntary retirement program. We are pleased with the results, especially given challenging market conditions during the quarter. 
So let's move to the average balance sheet on Page 5 of the presentation. Average commercial loan balances were relatively flat sequentially, but up about 5% year-over-year. Our end of period balances were up by $1.5 billion or 3% sequentially. The decline in average balances was partly due to higher pay downs and delays in closings at the very end of last year. We experienced healthy activity in the latter half of the first quarter. Average consumer loans were down 1% from last quarter and up 1% year-over-year.
Residential mortgage loans grew by 2% sequentially as we continue to portfolio only jumbo  mortgages and ARMs and up 11% year-over-year. Indirect auto loans are down 3% from last quarter and 5% year-over-year, in line with our lower origination targets and focus on improving returns in this business. The return profile of our first quarter production was one of the best in the last few years within the super-prime market that we mainly focus on. 
Average investment securities increased by $317 million in the first quarter or 1% sequentially. Average core deposits decreased $1 billion from the fourth quarter. This decrease was driven by seasonally lower demand deposits partially offset by higher interest checking balances. Our liquidity coverage ratio was very strong at 118% at the end of the quarter. 
Moving to NII on Page 6 of the presentation. Taxable equivalent net interest income increased by $5 million sequentially to $909 million, despite the negative day count impact. The increase was primarily driven by improvement in variable rate loan yields due to the increase in the fed funds rate in December, with deposit betas remaining at low levels. Quarter-over-quarter, our earning asset yield increased by 8 basis points accompanied by a 3 basis point increase in cost of interest-bearing liabilities. These benefits were partially offset by the effect of a reduced Fed stock dividend payment and continued spread compression from the mix shift to the lower-yielding, higher-quality credits, which we've discussed previously. 
NII also benefited from the timing of the investments in the portfolio, as cash flows were invested earlier in the quarter and the late debt issuance during the quarter. Overall, we are pleased with our NII growth over last quarter and the 7% growth year-over-year. NIM improved 6 basis points to 2.91% quarter-over-quarter.
Shifting to fees on Page 7 of the presentation. First quarter noninterest income was $637 million compared with $1.1 billion in the fourth quarter. Our fee income adjusted primarily for Vantiv-related items, and the annual $31 million TRA payment in the fourth quarter was $578 million, a decrease of $14 million or 2% sequentially. 
Despite seasonal headwinds and challenging market conditions, our results were strong. Corporate banking fees of $102 million were relatively flat sequentially and adjusted for the write-down of a residual lease in the first quarter of 2015 were up 10% year-over-year. 
As we mentioned in January, corporate banking fees are seasonally lower in the first quarter, and overall market conditions were weak during the quarter. So our performance was strong despite the challenging backdrop. 
Mortgage banking net revenue of $78 million was up $4 million sequentially. Originations were 1.8 billion in the first quarter, with 46% of the mix consisting of purchase volume. About 75% of the originations came from the retail and direct channels, and the remainder came through the correspondent channel. Gain on sale margins were up 57 basis points sequentially to 347 basis points, and net servicing asset valuation adjustments were negative $16 million similar to last quarter. 
Deposit service charges decreased 5% from the fourth quarter, reflecting seasonal trends in consumer deposit fees and increased 1% relative to the first quarter of 2015.
Total investment advisory revenue of $102 million was flat sequentially, mostly reflecting weaker equity market activity during the quarter. This impact was offset by seasonally higher trust tax preparation fees. Excluding certain onetime items, our year-over-year revenue growth reached nearly 5%, a very good outcome in a challenging environment.
Next, I would like to discuss noninterest expense on Page 8 of the presentation. Expenses were $986 million compared with $963 million in the fourth quarter. The sequential increase was partly due to seasonally higher FICA and employment insurance expense and a $14 million expense related to the voluntary early retirement program. The early retirement program was well received by our employees and approximately 160 employees participated. As a result, we expect a $9 million decrease in annual compensation expenses. 
As Greg said earlier, we continue to look for other similar opportunities to improve our expense run rate. I will provide an update on our expense outlook a little later.
Turning to credit results on Slide 9. Net charge-offs were $96 million or 42 basis points in the first quarter compared to $80 million and 34 basis points in the fourth quarter of 2015 and $91 million and 41 basis points in the first quarter a year ago. The sequential increase was due to a $16 million increase in C&I net charge-offs. Off the total net charge-offs, $9 million were in energy. Nonperforming loans, excluding loans held for sale, increased $195 million from the previous quarter to $701 million, resulting in an NPL ratio of 75 basis points.
Commercial NPLs increased $202 million from the fourth quarter, driven by $168 million in energy NPLs. Consumer NPLs declined by $7 million sequentially. 
Overall credit conditions, excluding energy, remained within our expectations. Consumer credit continues to improve, and commercial credit, excluding energy, is stable. Our provision was $23 million higher than the total charge-offs in the first quarter, and our reserve coverage moved up 1 basis point to 1.38% of loans and leases. It is important to note, as Greg mentioned, that an increase in energy NPLs should not necessarily translate into an increase in charge-offs of the same magnitude. This is because the majority of energy NPLs are well collateralized and consist of reserve-based loans.
On Slide 10, we have provided a breakdown of our energy portfolio. Our energy related loans at the end of the quarter were $1.7 billion with total commitments of $4 billion. As you can see, our loans to oilfield services companies were only $294 million or 17% of our total energy loans outstanding and leaves only $170 million in the unused commitments. 
We believe that we are appropriately reserved for losses in the energy portfolio based on detailed stress analysis that our teams continue to update not only on the oilfield services portfolio but also on our reserve-based loans. 
Based on detailed analysis, we believe that our energy reserves, which are currently at 6.2%, up from 4.8% at the end of last year, are adequate. Our stress case scenario over a 9 quarter period assumes that oil prices will be at $20 in 2016 and $25 in 2017.  This stress scenario would add approximately $50 million to $60 million in net charge-offs over and above our current results. 
On Slide 11, we provide a breakdown of our commercial real estate portfolio. It is important to note that our commercial real estate business today is much different than what we had precrisis. At the end of 2007, 21% of our total loans and leases were in commercial real estate. Today, we are at 11% below our peer levels.
At the end of 2007, over 40% of our nonowner-occupied exposure was in land and residential developers. Today, that exposure is slightly above 4%. As you can see, our nonperforming assets continue to decrease, both within the commercial mortgage and commercial construction portfolios.
At the end of the first quarter, NPAs in our commercial mortgage portfolio decreased to 1.84% from 2.56% a year earlier. NPAs in our commercial construction portfolio decreased to 23 basis points from 67 basis points over the same period. During the last 2 years, we significantly upgraded our credit resources in commercial mortgage and construction underwriting, which increased our focus on client selection, geographical diversity and multifactor stress analysis.
Moving on to capital on Slide 12. Our capital levels remain strong. Our common equity Tier 1 ratio was 9.8%, an increase of 30 basis points year-over-year. At the end of the first quarter, common shares outstanding were down approximately $15 million. During the quarter, we announced and settled a common stock repurchase of $240 million and reduced the first quarter's share count by 14.5 million shares.
Now moving to outlook. The drivers of our overall outlook remain unchanged. We expect year-over-year commercial loan growth to exceed 3% and the consumer loan portfolio to decline. The decline of our consumer loan portfolio will primarily reflect lower auto loan origination, as we had previously discussed, and includes the impact of the sales associated with the St. Louis and Pittsburgh transactions. 
Our interest rate outlook now has only one rate increase in June as opposed to the 2 increases that we had in our original base case. For the second quarter, we would expect relatively stable net interest income compared with the first quarter. But despite 1 late -- less rate increase, we still expect a 2.5% to 3% increase in NII year-over-year. In our base case, we would expect to see a 3 to 4 basis point of NIM decline in the second quarter and then hold relatively steady in line with our results in 2015. 
Although deposit betas are expected to remain low, our outlook assumes incremental spread compression due to our continued emphasis on originating higher quality loans. This update improves upon our January guidance as it includes 1 less rate increase. Without a rate increase, we would expect NII grow around 2%.
Our overall fee income growth outlook is not changing. We expect to grow our fees between 4% and 5% on the 2015 base of $2.3 billion, which excludes Vantiv share and warrant gains that we had during the year. We are lowering our year-over-year expense outlook from 4.5% to 5% to the 4% to 4.25% range. We believe that our intense focus on expense control will result in an improvement in operating efficiency compared to our January expectations.
The quarterly run rate will increase from the first quarter levels, and this will reflect seasonality and the timing of implementation of strategic initiatives. But we will have better year-over-year yield results than originally expected. Our second quarter results will also include a onetime approximately $10 million expense as a result of retirement eligibility changes related to long-term incentive compensation. These changes will align our retirement eligibility provisions with our peer group. This is just a change in the timing of the recognition of expenses and would lower our expense going forward. We continue to monitor our energy exposures closely. It is likely that we will see higher charge-offs in this portfolio, primarily in the oilfield services sector. Given the relatively modest size of our exposure, future credit losses should be manageable. Credit losses, ex energy, should remain in the range, with some potential variability quarter-to-quarter due to the historically low level of current charge-offs. 
With that, let me open the call for questions.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Ken Usdin from Jefferies.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tayfun, I was wondering if you could just follow up a little bit more on the credit outlook. You mentioned that we saw a big boost in the NPAs. You don't expect to see a lot more necessarily on the energy losses. But can you just flush out your confidence
componenttext: Tayfun, I was wondering if you could just follow up a little bit more on the credit outlook. You mentioned that we saw a big boost in the NPAs. You don't expect to see a lot more necessarily on the energy losses. But can you just flush out your confidence in seeing the underneath and if you could just parse out the portfolios what you're expecting in kind of commercial ex energy and on the consumer side?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Frank's here. Frank is going to answer that question.
componenttext: Sure. Frank's here. Frank is going to answer that question.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's good question. As we reported, the nonperforming assets are up in the quarter, almost all of that is energy related -- 90-plus percent is energy related. It's all tied to reserve-based lending loans, settled loans, we feel very confident at this poin
componenttext: It's good question. As we reported, the nonperforming assets are up in the quarter, almost all of that is energy related -- 90-plus percent is energy related. It's all tied to reserve-based lending loans, settled loans, we feel very confident at this point that those loans are protected by the risk adjustment collateral coverage that we have in place. All borrowers in this segment that are on NPL that were just moved are current, I think that's important. The regulators, as you probably heard on that earnings call, have taken a much stricter view on how they are classifying these loans from the accounting perspective. They are looking to cover both the first and the second lien positions on these companies. In our case, we have a super secured first-lien position, and we belong to a very detailed portfolio analysis that bottoms up of all of our energy book to ensure they're from the  borrowing base perspective, we're well secured. So NPLs are up. However, it's in the segment that's very well protected from a collateral position, but historically, they're based on a current outlook. We could see additional deterioration from an energy perspective in NPL, given that in the future as Tayfun indicated. But we are not changing our outlook on overall credit losses. Beyond that, when you look at the rest of the portfolio now, again, we talked this morning about commercial real estate. We feel very good about that book. The performance is holding up us very well. We have very little exposure in commercial real estate and the energy state. We have 4 multifamily credits that are in Houston, 2 of which are stabilized, the other 2 are performing under construction according to the terms that we've set. And we have some exposure in Denver from a commercial real estate perspective, but that market is held up very well not being in an energy sector. So the overall commercial real estate book at this point is performing to our expectations. Our middle market book is performing very well. We're showing very strong performance in most of our core markets. We're are not concerned there. Our leverage book is stable. We'll have some lumpiness quarter-to-quarter and leverage, but overall it's performing to our expectations as well. I hope that was responsive to your question.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was. And there is one quick follow-up. Tayfun, you'd previously talked about building reserves this year more reflecting loan growth. Is that also a reasonable expectation?
componenttext: It was. And there is one quick follow-up. Tayfun, you'd previously talked about building reserves this year more reflecting loan growth. Is that also a reasonable expectation?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, we will have to look at the reserve situation on a quarter-by-quarter basis. Obviously, we did say that reserve releases are very unlikely. And by the end of the year, our provisioning will reflect loan growth ultimately, but that's a quarter-by-qu
componenttext: Again, we will have to look at the reserve situation on a quarter-by-quarter basis. Obviously, we did say that reserve releases are very unlikely. And by the end of the year, our provisioning will reflect loan growth ultimately, but that's a quarter-by-quarter analysis that we will share with you.

componenttext: Yes. One thing to keep in mind, we're really not a Southwest bank. We don't have a resale present in the Southwest. We do other business there. Our commercial books held up very well. We don't see any deterioration from a traditional, commercial, middle market or mid-cap perspective. I just talked about real estate again. In Texas, we just have 4 transactions, $100 million in total exposure, multifamily to national developers. We see no problems there. If you switch over to indirect, we have about $1.5 billion in the energy states and indirect exposure, which is 4% of our total indirect.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's indirect auto loans.
componenttext: That's indirect auto loans.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Indirect. Well, it's a $1.5 billion in total indirect and consumer exposure, and the vast majority of that is in indirect auto loans. We've seen some uptick in past news in that  book. We cut off a number of dealer relationships in Texas in order to pulli
componenttext: Indirect. Well, it's a $1.5 billion in total indirect and consumer exposure, and the vast majority of that is in indirect auto loans. We've seen some uptick in past news in that  book. We cut off a number of dealer relationships in Texas in order to pulling out and shrink back that exposure. But overall, we feel good about the consumer indirect book in Texas. Other than that, we really don't have any substantial consumer exposure in the energy states. So again, our focus [indiscernible] concerns that would be around what we have in real estate, but it's small and it's well managed. And only indirect and the direct use of consumer is 4% of our portfolio.

componenttext: It's actually Steve Moss in for John. Wondering on with regard to the mix shift on loans going from -- going to lower-yielding, higher-quality loans. Wondering if you could just quantify what you're thinking about the impact to loan yields over the course of the year.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's going to be a function of basically the payoffs and originations. Originations are clearly coming at the upper end of our credit spectrum. In March, for example, when we looked at our commercial originations, the average grades were sort of very cl
componenttext: That's going to be a function of basically the payoffs and originations. Originations are clearly coming at the upper end of our credit spectrum. In March, for example, when we looked at our commercial originations, the average grades were sort of very close to the investment grade spectrum in our underwriting. Largely, the timing of the impact on margin will also depend on the payoffs from the lower end of the spectrum, and that's a little bit tough to quantify. We will quantify that for you each quarter as the quarter goes by, but it's a fairly steady type of tightening at this point.

componenttext: And one thing on our NIM outlook for the second quarter that's embedded in that is that C&I yields, the expectation would be down a couple of basis points as a result of that loan yield compression, as we continue to transition at higher credit profile clients.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of the spreads, the spreads this quarter were a good 25, 30 basis points above what we've seen over the past number of quarters. But I just want to remind you that, that was a very deliberate decision on our part to lower our annual originatio
componenttext: So in terms of the spreads, the spreads this quarter were a good 25, 30 basis points above what we've seen over the past number of quarters. But I just want to remind you that, that was a very deliberate decision on our part to lower our annual originations to roughly $3 billion from $5 billion, which enabled us to focus on profitability rather than volume. Our auto business is a national business that has not changed. The geographic distribution of originations is roughly about the same except for what Frank mentioned earlier. The spreads have lightened. The credit quality remains the same. So we're getting more return on the same type of capital allocation for the loans that we're originating.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and on the first quarter origination levels, that was a little bit ahead of $900 million or so, and that was a little bit ahead of our expectations frankly, given the pricing changes and the yields you've seen. So our outlook has increased the origin
componenttext: Yes, and on the first quarter origination levels, that was a little bit ahead of $900 million or so, and that was a little bit ahead of our expectations frankly, given the pricing changes and the yields you've seen. So our outlook has increased the originations from about $3 billion at the end of the year to about $3.3 billion for this year. And I think, you'll see yield expansion in the second quarter in that book.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Right now, we -- you saw on our book at the beginning of the quarter, January, February, we reinvested some cash flows because we saw little bit better entry points there. And then, you saw, we'd lightened on an end of period basis on the investment
componenttext: Yes. Right now, we -- you saw on our book at the beginning of the quarter, January, February, we reinvested some cash flows because we saw little bit better entry points there. And then, you saw, we'd lightened on an end of period basis on the investment portfolio as we closed out the quarter. So frankly, if rates were to stay at these pretty low levels, you could expect from us just to reinvest cash flows because the entry points don't look real good. But if rates were to have a little bit of a sell off here and present more opportunities, and you would expect our investment portfolio to grow in line with earning assets. But I don't think you will see a lot of moment in the book one way or the other throughout 2016.

componenttext: Yes, remember, when we were building for LCR, Matt, in the last 2 years, there was quite a bit more movement in the size of the portfolio, but looking out now, it's going to be steadier direction.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then if I could just follow up on a energy-related question. I'm curious in terms of the -- it looks like the overall outstanding balance hasn't really changed much quarter-over-quarter. But within that, are you seeing loan pay downs? Or other types
componenttext:
And then if I could just follow up on a energy-related question. I'm curious in terms of the -- it looks like the overall outstanding balance hasn't really changed much quarter-over-quarter. 
But within that, are you seeing loan pay downs? Or other types of cash flow in from those borrowers that is offsetting some potential drawdowns from other clients?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so overall -- this is Lars. We've seen pretty steady balances on overall basis in that portfolio as we continue to work through with our clients. What we did see in this past -- in the past quarter was commitment levels declined as we have reposition
componenttext: Yes, so overall -- this is Lars. We've seen pretty steady balances on overall basis in that portfolio as we continue to work through with our clients. What we did see in this past -- in the past quarter was commitment levels declined as we have repositioned and reduced our exposure level to a number of names. Accordingly, utilization rates moved up a little bit. But frankly, we would expect that those overall balances committed and loan balances would come down over a period of time, as the clients that we continue to work with very closely continue to sell off core, noncore assets, access the equity capital and debt capital markets and reduced our profile. But this is a great long-term business. We've got some expert bankers who're working very closely with our clients.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then, just finally on the auto loan portfolio. You mentioned your focus on prime and maybe even super prime in that portfolio. It doesn't look like from the 90-day past due volumes that that's changed very much. But can you just confirm that the asset quality in that portfolio really hasn't deteriorated much over the past 6 to 12 months?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
