headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so, I will ask Frank also try in and comment on the credit quality. Look, I think, we have seen a very significant change in the underlying credit factors, right? When you think about the decrease in NPLs, the decrease in criticized assets, those are
componenttext: Yes, so, I will ask Frank also try in and comment on the credit quality. Look, I think, we have seen a very significant change in the underlying credit factors, right? When you think about the decrease in NPLs, the decrease in criticized assets, those are meaningful, visible important changes. And again, results of some deliberate actions that we have taken over the past year or so. Beyond that obviously, they all contributed to, where we ended up with the results, but you have to keep in mind the reserve coverage all the way is down by 1 basis point and we even launching our peer group over the last 2, 3 quarters, we've seen more meaningful decreases in coverage from others and ours has been relatively stable, we're actually up compared to last year's third quarter. As we look forward, clearly if there is a significant change in the way that portfolio grows that we will reflect that in the provision as we said any significant environmental changes would expect provisions to move overall with loan growth and that probably is a statement that others have made. Frank, any color on soft of credit environment to that?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The work we done last 18 months to reposition the portfolio result of that we have $1 billion less in criticized assets this quarter, big number, very meaningful. We have taken about $1.4 billion for leverage book in the last 12 months and that was higher
componenttext: The work we done last 18 months to reposition the portfolio result of that we have $1 billion less in criticized assets this quarter, big number, very meaningful. We have taken about $1.4 billion for leverage book in the last 12 months and that was higher-risk piece of the leverage book. Our commodity exposure today is outstanding, it's $35 million. It's a all we have left. Where essentially out of the business. Our real estate exposure related to our peers is much lower, it is underwritten primarily to national and large regional developers we believe very, very accretive manner. And our energy is 2% of our total book. We are looking at and maybe $60 million to $80 million losses in energy that's over the next 8 to 9 quarters. So we have taken very deliberate actions with the work we are doing coordinated with commercial sides sort position these balance sheet to ensure we move towards the next recession, we're far better in control and in a far better position to be very successful in managing credit risk cycle. And so all of these I think are pretty self-evident today nonaccrual loans, again we talk about quarter after quarter. We will see some lumpiness like everybody does, but the most of our outlook is very positive for 2017 relative to credit all the different things and actions we have taken very deliberately a lot of discipline at last 18 months.

componenttext: Great, thanks for that color. So the follow-up to that point. You have gone to the -- it seems like more to the end of kind of cleaning up the book, cleaning out the book. I should say on the commercial side, aside from what the environment will give is it change philosophy in terms of like how fast you want to be growing in other parts of commercial? And where do you see the commercial side growth coming from?

componenttext: Yes. So first of all, I think Ken, you touch on a good point and in part of driven by the overall economic environment that's what we guide towards GDP. But as we continue to build out our industry verticals, those are continuing to provide nice lift for us, as well as drive an excellent fee income. And frankly, attractive returns for our shareholders. We are going to continue to focus on that. We are going to continue to build that industry expertise. But I would tell you in some of our core middle market regions we have seen nice growth in North Carolina, Chicago throughout the year, South Florida, Cincinnati. So we're going to continue to focus on execution, improving that client experience, investing in new industry verticals, and frankly growing, what is a very healthy commercial real estate portfolio, where we were really seen some nicely improved attractive asset quality metrics underwriting structure  that is much different from the last cycle, centralized and in expert line of business both on the line and with risk partners.

componenttext: Regarding North Side initiatives, just want to try to get a little bit more detail I know you just said that the amount of cost saves is about a third of the overall benefit that you expect out of the program. So of that cost-save component, could you give us an idea of the timing of the recognition as you move through '17 and then '18. Just trying to get idea how you really start to put that in numbers. headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of the way we look at Project North Star to give you a very broad picture. The qualification of the improvements in returns translates to a roughly $800 million type pretax income improvement between now and 2019. So the way we think about it
componenttext:
So in terms of the way we look at Project North Star to give you a very broad picture. The qualification of the improvements in returns translates to a roughly $800 million type pretax income improvement between now and 2019. So the way we think about it is, there is a base performance uplift from the businesses that we have and in a  case scenario, probably roughly it's about, let's call it a $3 million to $4 million we can do that by managing the expenses and then growing the revenue that already in play. And then, we look at certain balance sheet optimization targets that we are establishing. That probably I don't know let's call it sort of in the $100 million to $150 million range and then roughly another $150 million to $200 million in fee income growth. So that leaves somewhere around $150 million or so expense. These are broad numbers. We will share more details with you. 
The timing of the expense saves will start coming in 2017, some of them already in play, it is obviously major restructuring. And I think it will accelerate in 2018 and '19. Some of the projects underlying expense projects related to the commercial business and design that project is kicking off and it's going to have somewhat of a delayed impact, but again we would see probably more meaningful 2018 and then there are other investments that we are making. But that, that doesn't mean '17 does not have expand in play that also will contribute to '17. Those are the like to share with you as we approach the year-end and then beginning of the year.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me add a little bit to that. If you look at the SNC portfolio again which is $26 billion or about 49% of our total commercial booked. It's investment grade quality. If you exclude the energy piece of SNC for a moment, we have very low loss in that. Fo
componenttext: Let me add a little bit to that. If you look at the SNC portfolio again which is $26 billion or about 49% of our total commercial booked. It's investment grade quality. If you exclude the energy piece of SNC for a moment, we have very low loss in that. For criticized asset level is 3/4% from the entire SNC book. It's primarily an investment-grade portfolio.  Three quarters of that portfolio is, Lars said through deep relationships. About a quarter is credit only and a lot of those are fairly new relationships that we're building relationship on. So this is not a stand-alone portfolio that we are booked that we are buying just to grow portfolio. Its tied deeply into our strategy of dealing with relationships with top clients and I will tell you many of our relationships, we have a very meaningful piece of the when you look at the number of indicated facility. So we feel very good about it. I don't think at the end of the day, we will exceed 50% of our total book over time, but we unnecessarily have a problem with where it is relative to the performance and the fact that it's built in our core strategy of deepening of industry vertical in our MidCap relationship.

componenttext: Mike, it's great question and I don't know the answer. It really gets down, if you look over 50 variables as we mentioned before, we decided to close our consolidate the branch. So really is driven by the consumer preferences and you are seeing that migration and adoption to our mobile apps, our digital capabilities make 40 plus percent of all of our checks now coming in digital channels, 20% were mobile. So that's going to phase us, could it be another 10% plus, absolutely. So we're going to look at this every single year, we'll continue to test against it through the lens of 50 different variables we assessed and we will continue to make adjustments to our branch infrastructure. Obviously that helps us fund some more investments in digital cost, so we are looking for a transformational cost also as we reduce our branch infrastructure. But more to come there as far as the phase in the numbers, I'm not comfortable yet giving the number.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The thing to focus on leverage lending at least from our perspective all types of companies that are leverage. Where we had and where most of peers I think had issues had been overreliance on the enterprise value lending, financing M&A transactions and de
componenttext: The thing to focus on leverage lending at least from our perspective all types of companies that are leverage. Where we had and where most of peers I think had issues had been overreliance on the enterprise value lending, financing M&A transactions and deals wins sideways. So when they win sideways, the problem is loss and the default is very high. That's our prior experience. And as a result of that, we have been very judicious and going through as Lars just talked about looking at over client relationships, looking our sponsor relationship, looking at the types of credits that we would finance in a leverage environment, industries that we should consider and industries probably cyclical industries for example, we probably shouldn't consider financing leverage environment. So we talked about $1.4 billion reclassifying or leaving the books, is the highest risk piece that we focus on which are enterprise value deals, highly leveraged deals, clients who don't fit our risk profile, and leverage themselves out of our comfort zone. And those are the credits that we are moving out. So whether it's 10% or 20%, to me, it's a more meaningful number to that, because we're taking the highest risk in the portfolio and that's leaving the books and what remains is a portfolio that we think Greg well, we know well, with respect well, we have a great history and they have ability to manage leverage, because they leverage an industry that's much more stable versus much more cyclical. So I think, we know this well, we are repositioning ourselves in a place where we can continue to be delivering leverage finance to the right clients, client relationships, the right returns, about lot less volatility than what we had in the past.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would kind of go back to the prior question, this is about balance sheet management. This is about prudently using our capital and reinvesting it in the right kinds of relationships and it's not just about credit, it's about the entire relationshi
componenttext:
Well, I would kind of go back to the prior question, this is about balance sheet management. This is about prudently using our capital and reinvesting it in the right kinds of relationships and it's not just about credit, it's about the entire relationship, it's about the solutions and developing deep, strategic, advisory type relationships. And we are seeing that happened in play out on a go-forward basis. So I would just underscore, as I look across almost every business line that we have in the Commercial Bank, whether stabilized or slightly increased in some cases moderately increased our core loan spreads, which is allowed our company really to benefit from a large part of the rise that we have seen in LIBOR, where in some institutions, you are seeing some of that absorbed way with thinner spreads. 
Let me tell you something. The market is no easier today from a competitive environment perspective than it was several quarters ago. In fact, I would submit that it is more aggressive today and smaller banks are going up market, larger banks are going down market and non-banks are playing at levels we haven't seen before. So we are going to have to be at our best, but frankly, we have got great bankers with great businesses, I've got a lot of confidence in them that we can continue not just for four quarters, but for the long-term to produce.

componenttext: That's a great question. So asset-based lending, as you know, we not included in the leverage lending portfolio. But it's something is very attractive. When we are out with the client, we want to be very active and providing a broad range of solutions, including credit solutions. ABL has not been a growth area of this company. We have a new leader, we have a new team and a number of our producers, and we have new alignment both on the line and in credit, and we see it as a significant area of growth for us on a go-forward basis. One  of the benefits of that is, it's a very relationship-centric type expansion of credit with treasury management and other products and services and it also tends to outperform when the cycle turns, which is complementary to what Greg has shared with us is a vision for our company.

componenttext: Good morning, my name is Shelby and I'll be your conference operator. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Fifth Third Bank Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Sameer Gokhale, Head of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Shelby. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we'll be discussing our financial results for the third quarter of 2016. This discussion may contain certain forward-looking statements about Fifth Third, pertaining to our financial co
componenttext:
Thank you, Shelby. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Today, we'll be discussing our financial results for the third quarter of 2016. This discussion may contain certain forward-looking statements about Fifth Third, pertaining to our financial conditions, results of operations, plans and objectives. These statements involve risks and uncertainties that could cause results to differ materially from historical performance and these statements. We've identified some of these factors in our forward-looking cautionary statement at the end of our earnings release and in other materials, and we encourage you to review them. 
Fifth Third undertakes no obligation to and would not expect to update any such forward-looking statements after the date of this call. Additionally, reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures we referenced during today's conference call are included in our earnings release along with other information regarding the use of non-GAAP financial measures. A copy of our most recent quarterly earnings release can be accessed by the public in the Investor Relations section of our corporate website www.53.com This morning, I'm joined in the call by our President and CEO, Greg Carmichael; CFO, Tayfun Tuzun; Chief Operating Officer, Lars Anderson; Chief Risk Officer, Frank Forrest; and Treasurer, Jamie Leonard. Following prepared remarks by Greg and Tayfun, we will open the call up for questions.
Let me turn the call over now to Greg for his comments.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sameer. We thank all of you for joining us this morning. As you can see on Page 3 of the presentation, we reported third quarter net income to common shareholders of $501 million in earnings per diluted share of $0.65. During the quarter, some not
componenttext:
Thanks, Sameer. We thank all of you for joining us this morning. As you can see on Page 3 of the presentation, we reported third quarter net income to common shareholders of $501 million in earnings per diluted share of $0.65. During the quarter, some notable items resulted a net positive $0.22 impact reported earnings per share, Tayfun will provide further details in his opening comments.
During the quarter, we continue to focus on North Star initiative. Our Q3 results provide a further evidence of the progress we are making. Our net interest margin was well managed and stable sequentially reflecting our focus on higher-quality customer relationships. Adjusted fee income, excluding MSR evaluation adjustments was up 4% year-over-year and the growth rate has accelerated since the beginning of the year. Expenses were down 1% this quarter compared to second quarter 2016. During the quarter, credit quality remained stable with a decrease in both nonperforming loans and criticized asset levels for the second quarter in a row. The slight elevation in our charge-offs primarily reflects quarterly volatility from the low levels we have been experiencing.
We expect the benign credit environment to continue for the foreseeable future. Production metrics continue to be strong with mortgage volume up $2.9 billion, up 7% sequentially and up 27% from last year. Q3 volume represented the highest level record originations in the last 3 years.
In our Commercial business, we remained focused on higher-quality relationships that will enable our business to outperform through the cycle. As a result, commercial loan production for relationship manager is up 7% and fees for relationship manager up 22% on a year-to-date basis.  Our overall commercial loan balances reflect the soft loan demand which persisted during the quarter.
In regards to the environment, we will continue to focus on relationships that meet our return objectives. We're also investing in developing new origination channels. For example, during the quarter, we announced our strategic alliance with GreenSky, our investment in and partnership with GreenSky will help us to efficiently generate additional consumer loan volumes that will allow us to leverage the technology platform in existing merchant relationships.
While we continue to invest for growth in our businesses, we recognize that this remains a challenging environment for quality revenue growth. Given the limited support from a broader economic environment, we need to maintain a strong focus on expense management. We're all going to review across business and staff functions, we have already taken significant steps to reduce our expense base.
We completed the sale and consolidating of 108 branches this year, which is expected to drive approximately $60 million in the annualized cost savings. Last month, we announced plan to sell and consolidate an additional 22 big branches, which should generate incremental cost savings of $12 million annually.
As a result, total branches are expected to be down 12% since we began this process late last year. We expect these actions to generate run rate expense savings of $72 million annually. With rapid changes in technology and customer behavior, we'll continue to implement our omni-channel strategy. We believe this will allow us to further optimize our branch network, to best serve the needs of our customers.
We're also making the necessary technology investments to enhance our digital and operational capabilities. Our investments in the digital channel are paying off in the third quarter, approximately 20% of consumer deposits were made using our mobile app compared to 60% a year ago. Overall, we have seen a 25% increase in mobile usage year-over-year. We have also seen 150% increase year-over-year in checking and savings accounts opened online.
We expect to continue making investments to drive higher digital adoption and create a more integrated customer experience while creating efficiencies for Fifth Third.
To optimize workspace utilization, we are evaluating non-branch facilities for additional efficiencies. During the quarter, we sold one of our Michigan facilities, which generated $11 million pretax gain. We are working on similar opportunities to reduce the expense run rate or improving the overall work environment for our employees.
We also renegotiated key vendor contracts during the quarter as disclosed earlier. As a result of our strong execution and focus on expense management, we now expect year-over-year expense growth to be sub 4% in 2016 compared to our original guidance of 4.5% to 5% at the start of the year. The actions we're taking should help us achieve positive operating leverage in 2017. Although near-term expense management is at the top of our priority list, we are also maintaining a long-term perspective on our strategic plans.
During the third quarter, we formally launched Project North Star to align our entire organization towards a higher and more sustainable level of profitability within the next 3 years. Our energies are focused on ensuring the right mix of expense reductions, key revenue enhancement opportunities and balance sheet optimization in order to achieve our ROTCE targets.
Assuming the current operating environment persist, we would expect to achieve a 12% to 14% ROTCE run rate by the end of 2019.
We expect the contributions from Project North Star to be additive to the improvements that we're already making in our base run rate. These initiatives will leverage our strength in middle market lending, industry verticals with special lending areas in our commercial business and the consumer business growth initiatives in mortgage banking and personal lending will provide support for more balanced growth in our overall loan portfolio. We continue to expand our capabilities in businesses such as capital markets, insurance, and wealth management that generate attractive returns.
Initiatives such as our commercial end-to-end process redesign project will help generate additional efficiencies while improving the overall customer experience. We intend to achieve these targets without changing our risk appetite for our ongoing discipline and maintaining a strong balance sheet.
Our capital and liquidity levels remain strong and improved from last quarter. Our common equity Tier 1 ratio reached 10.16% from 9.94% at the end of the second quarter. And our liquidity coverage ratio was 115%, 25% above the current requirement. 
As previously disclosed, the Federal Reserve did not object to an increase in our common dividend of $0.14 per share in the fourth quarter.
In summary, I was pleased with the solid results we generated despite soft economic conditions. Our results demonstrate the progress we are making toward our targets on our Project North Star as well as our longer-term strategic goals. Also I want to thank all of our employees for their hard work and dedication and for keeping the customer at the center of everything we do.
With that I will turn over to Tayfun to discuss our third quarter operating results and current outlook.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Let's move to the financial summary on Page 4 of the presentation. As Greg said, overall we are pleased with our results in the current economic environment. The growth in our net interest income,
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Good morning, and thank you for joining us. Let's move to the financial summary on Page 4 of the presentation. As Greg said, overall we are pleased with our results in the current economic environment. The growth in our net interest income, the stability of the net interest margin and the decline in our expenses are indicative of our focus on improving shareholder returns.
For the third quarter, there was a net positive impact of $0.22 per share resulting from several items. The most significant item was a $280 million pretax gain from the termination and settlement of certain Vantiv TRA growth cash flows and the expected obligation to terminate and settle remaining TRA gross cash flows.
Our underlying fee revenues were solid during the quarter. Mortgage origination and pass through fees were 31% higher in the third quarter on a year-over-year basis.
Corporate Banking revenues were seasonally down slightly from our robust second quarter as we have previously indicated.
Expenses continue to be tightly controlled as we continue to look for efficiencies throughout the organization. The quarter-over-quarter improvement in overall key credit risk indicators is supportive of the benign credit outlook. So with that, let's move to Page 5 for the balance sheet discussion. Average commercial loan balances decreased 1% sequentially and increased about 1% year-over-year. The sequential decline reflected some softness in C&I loan demand and was consistent with industry trends. Our spreads widened as we continued to reposition and optimize the portfolio into a more attractive risk return profile that we believe will be more resilient in an economic downturn. 
Our C&I yield has increased every quarter since the third quarter of last year. CRE growth of $354 million this quarter partially offset some of the decline in C&I balances. As we discussed before, in construction as well as in perm lending, our teams are cognizant of valuations and supply-demand dynamics created by the lack of attractive investment alternatives. Our disciplined client selection and credit underwriting in CRE will continue to rely on stringent standards.
Average consumer loans decreased $78 million from last quarter and were down 2% year-over-year. Auto loans were down 3% from last quarter and 12% year-over-year in line with our loan origination targets and focus on improving risk-adjusted returns in this business.
Our strategy so far this year has resulted in higher returns on assets and capital than our initial expectations in our indirect auto business.
Residential Mortgage loans grew by 3% sequentially and 10% year-over-year as we kept jumbo mortgages, ARMs as well as certain 10- and 15-year fixed-rate mortgages on our balance sheet during the quarter.
Our Residential Mortgage originations were up 7% from last quarter and 27% year-over-year.
During the quarter, our origination mix was split roughly in half between purchase and refinance volumes. About 70% of the originations came from the retail and direct channels, and the remainder were originated through the corresponding channel.
Our home equity loan portfolio decreased 2% sequentially and 7% year-over-year as low -- loan paydowns exceeded strong origination volume. Our originations this quarter were up 15% compared to last quarter and 20% higher year-over-year.
Our goal is to achieve a better balance between commercial loan growth and consumer loan growth. Our new partnership with GreenSky should help enhance our ability to generate consumer loans, especially as we start to implement their technology in our own business.
In addition, our new initiatives in credit card lending should also support stronger growth going forward. Average investment securities decreased by $239 million in the third quarter or 1% sequentially.
Our yield widened by 2 basis points quarter-over-quarter, partly due to higher discount accretion during the quarter. Average core deposits decreased $98 million from the second quarter. Average core deposit balances were negatively impacted by approximately $302 million due to the Pennsylvania branches sold in April. Excluding these deposits, average core deposits were flat on a sequential basis and up 1% on a year-over-year basis. Our liquidity coverage ratio was very strong at 115% at the end of the quarter. 
Moving to NII on Page 6 of the presentation. Taxable equivalent net interest income increased by $5 million sequentially to $913 million. The increase was primarily driven by improved investment portfolio yields, an increase in 1-month LIBOR and the impact of the day count. The increase was partially offset by the full quarter impact of $1.25 billion of unsecured debt issued late in the second quarter and lower average C&I loan balances.
The NIM was stable from the second quarter at 2.88% and wider than we forecasted in July. The positive impact of higher-yielding investments and an increase in 1-month LIBOR was offset by the full quarter impact of the second quarter debt issuance and the day count.
Our outlook for NIM has improved relative to our July forecast. With no rate hikes for the rest of the year, we now expect the NIM to be stable to down 1 basis point in the fourth quarter, which includes the full quarter impact of our September debt issuance.
On a full-year basis, we would expect the NIM of about 2.89%, which is up 1 basis point from 2015. We expect NII to be down slightly in the fourth quarter from the full quarter impact of our third quarter debt issuance and more normalized discount accretion on the investment securities portfolio. We are still projecting full year NII growth of 2% despite ongoing challenges with the low environment, the rate environment and stable loan growth.
We will continue to execute a balanced interest rate risk management strategy as we have over the last 3 years. Our NIM outperformance should not imply that we have outsized the exposure to a decline in portfolio yields. We estimate that in a static interest rate environment, the investment portfolio would only have a detrimental impact of 2 basis points in 2017 on the Bancorp's net interest margin. A key contributor to this stability is that approximately 48% of our investment portfolio consists of lockout and bullet securities. Keeping nearly our entire investment portfolio in the available for sale category has also allowed us to maintain some flexibility to reposition the investment portfolio in response to changing market conditions.
Shifting to fees on Page 7 of the presentation. Third quarter noninterest income was $840 million compared with $599 million in the second quarter. Our fee income, adjusted for items disclosed in our earnings release was $596 million. Also excluding the impact of the net MSR valuation, fee revenue was up 2% versus last quarter and up 4% compared to the third quarter of 2015. Despite the environmental factors, our underlying fee revenues were solid, mortgage production gains on sale were up 13% quarter-over-quarter reflecting the robust origination value and that I've mentioned earlier, and a 39 basis points increase in the gain on sale margin.
Mortgage banking net revenue of $66 million was down $9 million sequentially, primarily due to net MSR valuation adjustments during the quarter. Net MSR valuation adjustments were negative $9 million compared to a positive $6 million last quarter. We expect our fourth quarter mortgage origination revenue to be seasonally lower than the third quarter by 5% to 10% above last year's fourth quarter.
Corporate Banking fees of $111 million were seasonally down $6 million or 5% sequentially reflecting decreases in loan syndication revenue and foreign exchange fees, partially offset by an increase in corporate bond underwriting revenue. Fees were up 7% on a year-over-year basis, driven by a strong corporate bond underwriting and loan syndication revenues.
The expansion highlights are efforts to increase the scale and scope of our product offering in line with the relationship driven model that we are executing. We expect Corporate Banking fees in the fourth quarter to be stable relative to the third quarter.
Deposit service charges increased 4% from the second quarter, driven by a 6% increase in retail service charges as well as a 3% increase in commercial service charges. The increase in retail service charges reflected seasonally higher customer activity. Deposit service charges decreased 1% relative to the third quarter of 2017 -- 2015 reflecting reduced monthly service charges as part of our new consumer checking account lineup.
Total wealth and asset management revenue of $101 million was flat sequentially as market value improvements were offset by lower transaction-driven retail brokerage fees. Revenues declined 2% relative to the third quarter of 2015 as investment management and institutional fees were more than offset by lower brokerage fees.
We discussed the third quarter impact of the Vantiv TRA transactions in July during our second quarter earnings call. These transactions were very beneficial from both risk management as well as shareholder return optimization perspectives.
As you may recall, our prior guidance for 2016 called for a 5% annual adjusted fee growth off a base of $2.3 billion for 2015. This base excluded impact from Vantiv as previously discussed, which I mentioned on Slide 11 of our presentation.
Excluding Vantiv-related items, the Visa total return swap adjustments and any impacts from the branch sales and consolidations, we continue to expect annual fees growth of 5% growth for the full year.
Next, I'd like to discuss noninterest expense on Page 8 of the presentation. Expenses of $973 million were $10 million lower than in the second quarter, including the impact of the FDIC surcharge. This reflects a decrease in compensation-related expenses and employee benefits resulting from the impact of the second quarter of 2016 retirement eligibility change as well as other reductions in operational expenses.
As Greg stated earlier, we are making good progress in executing on key strategic initiatives and managing our expenses at the same time. We now expect expense growth to be below 4% level compared to our July guidance of 4% and 4.5% to 5% at the start of the year.
Once again, I would like to remind you that our guidance includes the impact of the increased amortization of our low income housing investments, which most of our peers reflect in their tax line. On an annual basis, this line item contributes nearly 3% to our efficiency ratio. It also includes an increase in the provision for unfunded commitments and the impact of one-time benefits related to settlement of legal cases in 2015. These 3 items make up roughly 2% of the forecasted increase in expenses.
As we have previously discussed, generating positive operating leverage is our top priority going into 2017, and our recent trends are supportive of that outcome.
Turning to credit results on Slide 9. Net charge-offs were $107 million or 45 basis points in the third quarter compared to $87 million and 37 basis points in the second quarter of 2016, and $188 million and 80 basis points in the third quarter a year ago. The sequential increase in charge-offs was primarily due to a $22 million increase in C&I net charge-offs.
Total nonperforming loans, excluding loans held-for-sale were $506 million, down $107 million or 15% from the previous quarter resulting in an NPL ratio of 63 basis points. Commercial NPLs decreased $94 million or 17% from the second quarter. In addition, our criticized assets have steadily improved over the last four quarters and our criticized asset ratio is now at the lowest point since the third quarter of 2007.
The strength in the key credit metrics indicate continued overall stability, but given the absolute low levels, there may be volatility in some periods periodically.
Our provision was $11 million lower than the last quarter, partially driven by improving nonperforming loan and criticized asset levels. Our resulting reserve coverage as a percent of loans and leases decreased 1 basis point to 1.37%, but was up 2 basis points from last year. Our previous guidance and net charge-offs would be range bound with some quarterly variability is unchanged. We expect the fourth quarter charge-offs to be lower than the third quarter charge-offs. Also we continue to believe that our provision expense will be primarily reflective of loan growth.
Moving on to capital and liquidity on Slide 10. Our capital levels remain strong and are growing. Our common equity Tier 1 ratio was 10.16%, an increase of 22 basis points quarter-over-quarter and 76 basis points year-over-year.
At the end of the third quarter, common shares outstanding were down approximately $11 million or 1.4% compared to the second quarter of 2016 and down 40 million shares or 5% compared to last year's third quarter.
During the quarter, we executed and accelerated share repurchase of $240 million, which reduced the share count by 10.98 million shares. This repurchase includes our 2016 FICO repurchases as well as the third quarter after-tax cash flows realized from the Vantiv TRA termination and settlement.
Our book value and tangible book value are up 12% and 13% respectively year-over-year. We expect our fourth quarter tax rate to be in the 23.5% to 24.5% range.
This quarter, we would be finalizing our 2017 financial plan as well as our outlook for Project North Star, which is a 3-year project. As Greg said, we expect Project North Star to contribute meaningfully to our base performance, which we expect to improve independently compared to our more recent performance.
The priorities embedded within the North Star project are an intense focus on expense management, smart balance sheet management and capital efficiency and revenue growth initiatives in high return businesses. These expectations include higher than historical growth in personal lending, including credit cards, expansion of our middle market and vertical businesses in commercial and widening the scope and scale in our capital markets businesses.
Expense savings should include lower infrastructure and delivery costs in IT, lower total compensation costs and other operational expense savings in workspace management, legal work and savings related to a more efficient data infrastructure and end-to-end process redesign. This quarter we are working on finalizing our 2017 financial plan as well as the construct of our Project North Star. Our goal is to share our expectations with you later this quarter and more in our January call. We have included the updated outlook on Slide 11 for your reference. And with that, let me turn it over to Sameer to open the call up for Q&A.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Jill Shea with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on the loan growth side, can you provide us some color in terms of what you're hearing from customers and just any color in terms of overall demand? And then just how much is the [indiscernible] related to the environment and softness in demand and h
componenttext: Just on the loan growth side, can you provide us some color in terms of what you're hearing from customers and just any color in terms of overall demand? And then just how much is the [indiscernible] related to the environment and softness in demand and how much is actually related to deliberate going back in terms of relationships for industries?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Jill, this is Lars. And just a few comments there. First of all, what we're hearing from clients? They continue to be cautious, reticent about making significant investments. I think that you have seen some of that play out in the lower M&A activi
componenttext: Yes. So Jill, this is Lars. And just a few comments there. First of all, what we're hearing from clients? They continue to be cautious, reticent about making significant investments. I think that you have seen some of that play out in the lower M&A activity that we've seen as we've headed further into the year. That uncertainty also revolves around questions of the political, what's going on with China, Brexit, the EU-type issues. So those are certainly coloring some of the investments that we're seeing. We did clearly see a slower production in the third quarter, but I would see that as a little bit more seasonal, which we typically see lower levels in July and August. So I'd say it was more pronounced this third quarter, however, with the things that we're doing, investing in our verticals, new businesses and frankly, we've got some geographies, some markets that are performing very well. I would expect that we would continue to see loan growth at a good stable rate on a go-forward basis. We've got a great business model, one that clearly has been well received in the marketplace, our advisory base relationship model as long as that's embraced and we're seeing that reflect it in deeper client relationships that's helping us to drive fee income.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks. That's very helpful. And then maybe just quickly on the margin. It held up quite nicely this quarter. Can you just walk through the moving parts there? I think you spoke to some of that in your opening remarks in terms of the loan and secur
componenttext: Great, thanks. That's very helpful. And then maybe just quickly on the margin. It held up quite nicely this quarter. Can you just walk through the moving parts there? I think you spoke to some of that in your opening remarks in terms of the loan and securities yields. But could you just walk us through your expectations keeping that margin stable sequentially as we move forward? Maybe just the puts and takes there?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, yes, we obviously were happy to see a stable margin, a good amount of that is due to what just Lars just talked about on disciplined pricing on the commercial side, we actually, as I mentioned, have been able to increase our C&I yield four q
componenttext: Yes. I think, yes, we obviously were happy to see a stable margin, a good amount of that is due to what just Lars just talked about on disciplined pricing on the commercial side, we actually, as I mentioned, have been able to increase our C&I yield four quarters in a row now that is helping out very focused management of the investment portfolio. Environmental factors clearly have played out very similar to the way we envisioned them and the investment portfolio is contributing a lot to, Jamie, anything else you want to add to the margin side?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As Tayfun mentioned, the third quarter walk is what we would expect some of these to recur in the fourth quarter. So from the second quarter to the third quarter, loan yield expansion was 1 basis point of improvement and then the investment portfolio
componenttext: Yes. As Tayfun mentioned, the third quarter walk is what we would expect some of these to recur in the fourth quarter. So from the second quarter to the third quarter, loan yield expansion was 1 basis point of improvement and then the investment portfolio discount accretion was another 2 basis points on top of that, and then that was offset by the day count, in fact of negative 1 basis point and the debt funding impacts of negative 2 basis points. So what we expect going forward for the fourth quarter, obviously has been an active year on the debt side for us and we've refinanced all of our maturities for the year. So the debt you can expect to be pretty quiet, but the loan yield expansion that we've seen every quarter this year, we expect to continue into the fourth quarter and that for us is driven by C&I and auto yields, they both increased 3 basis points in the third quarter and then the one anomaly from the third quarter will be the investment portfolio had tremendous performance in the third quarter with the discount accretion. You saw that as how we're obviously pleased with how we're positioned on the portfolio, but that should normalize in the fourth quarter just given the faster speeds in the third quarter than what we're expecting in the fourth quarter so that would be a little bit of headwind for us in the fourth quarter. But I think the loan yields and the other actions we've taken to generate either a stable NIM or perhaps down a basis point and that assumes there is no said increase in the fourth quarter.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gill, and if I could just tag on, this has been a very deliberate strategy over the past years. We focused on balance sheet management and redeploying our capital into businesses that we felt that we could get better returns. By stabilizing our core coupo
componenttext: Gill, and if I could just tag on, this has been a very deliberate strategy over the past years. We focused on balance sheet management and redeploying our capital into businesses that we felt that we could get better returns. By stabilizing our core coupon, we have been able to benefit more from the LIBOR rise than many of our peers and we're going to continue to do that. And in fact that's part of our North Star's strategy.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And beyond the fourth quarter, we stand by our statement that we made last quarter that we see stability in 2017 without any rate increases and what's encouraging is, when you take a look at the debt refinancings that we had this year, 2017 is a relativel
componenttext: And beyond the fourth quarter, we stand by our statement that we made last quarter that we see stability in 2017 without any rate increases and what's encouraging is, when you take a look at the debt refinancings that we had this year, 2017 is a relatively lighter year. So that also would be supportive of that stable outlook for 2017.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Erika Najarian with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Erika Najarian with Bank of America.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I just needed to ask a follow-up question. You mentioned that beyond fourth quarter, you see stability in the net interest margin without a rate hike. I'm wondering as you continue to go through the balance sheet optimization, which is clearly benefici
componenttext: So I just needed to ask a follow-up question. You mentioned that beyond fourth quarter, you see stability in the net interest margin without a rate hike. I'm wondering as you continue to go through the balance sheet optimization, which is clearly beneficial to margin. How should we think about average earning asset growth going forward? It's been flattish this year. And I'm wondering if some of the heavy lifting in terms of exiting certain portfolios is going to abate next year and perhaps average earning asset first could pick up?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And thanks for your question Erika. This is Greg. First off, we have done a lot of heavy lifting in our last year plus and really exiting out of all the sectors and focusing on profitability whether it be commodities, term loan fee, leverage loans. We bas
componenttext: And thanks for your question Erika. This is Greg. First off, we have done a lot of heavy lifting in our last year plus and really exiting out of all the sectors and focusing on profitability whether it be commodities, term loan fee, leverage loans. We basically have pushed out close to almost $2 billion over the last year. So while that's going to abate as we go into 2017, 2018, a lot of heavy lifting is going to be done, and has been done this year. So we can think about next year as we look into the forward forecast, we expect commercial loan growth to be close to nominal on GDP, maybe slightly north of that on consumer, given some of our focus on indirect auto and bringing down the originations there we expect that to be flat to slightly up next year as we focused on other opportunities such as mortgage and unsecured lending as Tayfun mentioned in his opening comments. And those you wanted to add any of that Lars [indiscernible] .

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will be finalizing this outlook obviously a bit firmer in January. Don't take this as a guidance for 2017, but the trends that Greg mentioned fairly are intact.
componenttext: We will be finalizing this outlook obviously a bit firmer in January. Don't take this as a guidance for 2017, but the trends that Greg mentioned fairly are intact.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would just emphasize, again this has been a very deliberate plan of balance sheet management and to ensure that we are optimizing our capital and our liquidity from a corporate perspective. And is in alignment with our relationship banking strategy
componenttext: Yes, I would just emphasize, again this has been a very deliberate plan of balance sheet management and to ensure that we are optimizing our capital and our liquidity from a corporate perspective. And is in alignment with our relationship banking strategy. And I will tell you, one of the complements to this is, as we build out businesses such as the verticals where we are delivering specialized industry expertise it's also helping us to feed our capital markets business and drive that at rates that are far beyond the expansion of what has been pretty much a flat industry, we've been growing our capital markets in the 14%, 15% rate.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the other comment, I would make Erika is away from the commercial portfolio, our decision to take down auto loan originations at the start of this year had an impact clearly on total loan growth. On an average-to-average basis compared to last year's
componenttext: And the other comment, I would make Erika is away from the commercial portfolio, our decision to take down auto loan originations at the start of this year had an impact clearly on total loan growth. On an average-to-average basis compared to last year's third quarter, our auto loan portfolio balances are down $1.3 billion. So making those adjustments and focusing on sort of capital returns and other balance sheet targets, actually we are quite pleased with where we are with respect to where our balance sheet is today.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And my follow-up question is, I thought you made a very important point on the defensiveness of your securities yield. Could you explain further what exactly it means to how, I'm just looking back [indiscernible] it's 48% of your investment portfo
componenttext: Got it. And my follow-up question is, I thought you made a very important point on the defensiveness of your securities yield. Could you explain further what exactly it means to how, I'm just looking back [indiscernible] it's 48% of your investment portfolio and lockout or bullet securities as we think about in a static environment for the yield curve, why that's not going to pressure the yields further?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for that question. And I'm going to ask Jamie to provide some details. We have seen some writeups during the quarter that clearly had a different tone than what we are seeing. So it's important for us to provide you more details about our quality.
componenttext: Thanks for that question. And I'm going to ask Jamie to provide some details. We have seen some writeups during the quarter that clearly had a different tone than what we are seeing. So it's important for us to provide you more details about our quality. Jamie?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what's important about is, Erika is that and one of the changes we actually made in the disclosure of this quarter was that when you have 48% of the portfolio, our last quarter is 51%. We actually updated that disclosure to reflect the 24-month time
componenttext: Yes, what's important about is, Erika is that and one of the changes we actually made in the disclosure of this quarter was that when you have 48% of the portfolio, our last quarter is 51%. We actually updated that disclosure to reflect the 24-month time horizon whereas prior times we've discussed that we just looked out at 12 months, but obviously this is a big focus item for our all of the analysts and investors just given the outperformance in the yield, and the point in updating the disclosure was the same in the next 24 months about half of our portfolio, we will not have cash flows returned to us. And we've talked every quarter about whether we were or we're not going to reinvest cash flows out of the portfolio in the third quarter. We didn't like the entry points we were seeing and so we didn't reinvest over half the cash flows from the portfolio, but the total level of cash flows that come off the portfolio are a pretty low level as a percent of our book relative to our peers. And that's really where you can dig in and see when folks are invested in pass-through securities you have extension risk and you have pre-payment risk and the bullet locked out cash flow play that we have been running for over 2 years and talking you about that, really benefits in the environment that we're seeing today. And that's why we're very pleased with how we're positioned. We're obviously, over long-term time horizon going to be subject to market yields and next year that will be about a 2 basis point NIM impact, the rates were to stay where they were today. But overall, this is just not a big risk for Fifth Third given how we position the portfolio.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that we have seen it in the third quarter with respect to how this kind of accretion played against premium amortization that was deliberately done. We positioned the portfolio for potentially higher prepayment. So I think all-in-all, we're pretty ple
componenttext: And that we have seen it in the third quarter with respect to how this kind of accretion played against premium amortization that was deliberately done. We positioned the portfolio for potentially higher prepayment. So I think all-in-all, we're pretty pleased with where the portfolio stands.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Christopher Marinac with FIG Partners.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Want to delve into the GreenSky relationship and I was curious, we will see balances in the fourth quarter from that and also how many quarters in the future until the technology is beginning to be implemented systemwide?
componenttext: Want to delve into the GreenSky relationship and I was curious, we will see balances in the fourth quarter from that and also how many quarters in the future until the technology is beginning to be implemented systemwide?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, Christopher, we're on-boarding on assets, as we speak. And we're very pleased with the initial power phase that we're in right now, the average FICO that we're boarding right now is about 750. So we're on-boarding assets as we speak, we targeted ro
componenttext: First, Christopher, we're on-boarding on assets, as we speak. And we're very pleased with the initial power phase that we're in right now, the average FICO that we're boarding right now is about 750. So we're on-boarding assets as we speak, we targeted roughly $90 million to $100 million a quarter is what our forward-looking expectations are for asset generation of GreenSky. On a technology front, we're going to focus on 2 phases. First phase is our digital adoption, deploying through our digital channels, our mobile web-based applications that will start to roll out second quarter next year that's what we are targeting for right now. And then after that, we will focus on the branch adoption of the technology which is probably of early 2017, early 2018.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Burnell with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tayfun, let me start by asking a question on the margin. And I know you haven't spend a lot of time talking about 2017. But if we were to get a 25 basis point hike in late December, I presume that doesn't have much effect on the December -- sorry on the f
componenttext: Tayfun, let me start by asking a question on the margin. And I know you haven't spend a lot of time talking about 2017. But if we were to get a 25 basis point hike in late December, I presume that doesn't have much effect on the December -- sorry on the fourth quarter margin. But last year, the margin was up about 6 basis points from the fourth quarter -- sorry for the first quarter '16 after the hike in the fourth quarter. And I'm curious, if you're positioning is similar to that now, where we would -- where you might expect a roughly similar benefit from a 25 basis point hike. And then if that occurs, what you're thinking about margin through the course of the year. Since this year, the margin sort of worked its way back down after the initial benefit in the first quarter?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt, this is Jamie. I will take that one. The benefit to us if the Fed were to move in the second week of December is about 1 basis point to margin benefit and that's what we saw in the fourth quarter of '15 with that move. When you do dissect the m
componenttext: Yes, Matt, this is Jamie. I will take that one. The benefit to us if the Fed were to move in the second week of December is about 1 basis point to margin benefit and that's what we saw in the fourth quarter of '15 with that move. When you do dissect the margin transition from 4Q '15 to 1Q '16, we were up 6 bps, 8 of that actually was driven by the Fed move. So our view on December 2016 move were to happen is probably going to be slightly less beneficial than the 8 basis points that we saw last year, just given the deposit rates maybe a little more competitive on the second move and each prospective move. So I think on the high side, it'd be 8 and then we're looking at this more in the 6 range. But yes, we are positioned that it would be very beneficial to us and then as Tayfun said, part of the change that occurred from 4Q '15 to where we are today on the margin was in a large part driven by the $3.7 billion of debt maturities we had this year, and now that, next year, we're at a $1.2 billion level of maturities that was really the biggest influence on the margin compression this year that, that obviously would not repeat. And therefore, you would expect some stability to growth in the NIM going forward if the Fed were to be raising rates.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then for my follow-up, let me ask about deposit growth. It seems relative to others who have reported so far this quarter that your deposit growth, even adjusting for the sale is relatively flattish, many other banks have almost
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then for my follow-up, let me ask about deposit growth. It seems relative to others who have reported so far this quarter that your deposit growth, even adjusting for the sale is relatively flattish, many other banks have almost been complaining about the level of deposit growth relative to loan growth. How much of your client optimization activities have been -- have affected deposit growth and what other trends are you seeing in deposit growth that you think might improve over the next couple of quarters?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you have a look at that picture from 2 sides, one is commercial, the other one is consumer. On the consumer side, I think we expect to continue to grow the consumer book at healthy levels. On the commercial side, almost the entire decline has been
componenttext: I think you have a look at that picture from 2 sides, one is commercial, the other one is consumer. On the consumer side, I think we expect to continue to grow the consumer book at healthy levels. On the commercial side, almost the entire decline has been on deliberate customer actions and those are unlikely to repeat at that level, and given our plans in the treasury management business and the expansion of our relationships, we would expect to get back on a growth pattern in commercial deposits.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk a bit about the underlying expense growth if you think about exiting this year into next, obviously 2016 was a big year on the technology, the compliance spend, has that peaked and just what are some of the puts and takes and any comments on
componenttext: Can you talk a bit about the underlying expense growth if you think about exiting this year into next, obviously 2016 was a big year on the technology, the compliance spend, has that peaked and just what are some of the puts and takes and any comments on the overall expense growth that you think about next year?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll make a few comments, and I will turn it over to Tayfun, First of, we're fully committed and we expect to have positive operating leverage as we go into 2017 so that's number one objective. We'll  continue to stay focused on expenses. As I mentioned i
componenttext: I'll make a few comments, and I will turn it over to Tayfun, First of, we're fully committed and we expect to have positive operating leverage as we go into 2017 so that's number one objective. We'll  continue to stay focused on expenses. As I mentioned in prior discussions, on our technology investment, the higher watermark will be 2016. So we expect our technology investments to subside as we go into 2017 and 2018, not the current levels we're seeing today at 2016. So we expect that to improve. In addition, to that, we mentioned before on Project North Star, as you think about Project North Star, 1/3 of the opportunity benefit we get from Project North Star's is expense improvement. We expect to see that start to impact our run rate in 2017, some of the actions we have already taken and the actions that we have planned coming forward. So, Tayfun, if you want to pull the buckle on that.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it could be too early to provide more detailed outlook on '17, Matt. But we clearly, our key thing is very close eye on compensation expenses and at the accounts. So that is going to help us. And as we said many times here, over the last 2 or 3 quart
componenttext: Yes, it could be too early to provide more detailed outlook on '17, Matt. But we clearly, our key thing is very close eye on compensation expenses and at the accounts. So that is going to help us. And as we said many times here, over the last 2 or 3 quarters or even going beyond that to late '15, we expected and we did achieve a peak on our risk and compliance-related headcounts and going forward that type of increase is unlikely to repeat itself. Some of these larger vendor contracts in 2017 will be hitting our expense line on a full-year basis, which is going to be beneficial. There is going to be workspace management sales, some related to branch closing, some related to broader tactics and strategies that our team is executing there. So there is a combination of factors that indicate to us that this expectation of positive operating leverage even in a static environment is achievable.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: And then just separately a clarification question regarding next year, you have said, I think the NIM percent was going to be stable? componenttext: Yes, we're already basically [indiscernible] going into the full-year NIM and at this point, Matt, it's too early to give you an NII guidance for 2017.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your credit quality continues to be very good aside from the points you made about the variability, we're seeing the pretty sizable release this quarter and you still have a upper 1/3 type of reserve ratio, with the move to also build consumer going forwa
componenttext: Your credit quality continues to be very good aside from the points you made about the variability, we're seeing the pretty sizable release this quarter and you still have a upper 1/3 type of reserve ratio, with the move to also build consumer going forward, you mentioned that provisioning would be in line with loan growth. Can you just help us think about, just how much improvement do you still see us underneath the surface and what you would be concerned about as far as any variability in other parts of the book?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so, I will ask Frank to also try him and comment on the credit quality. Look, and only I think, we have seen a very significant change in the underlying credit factors, right? When you think about the decrease in NPLs, the decrease in criticized asse
componenttext: Yes, so, I will ask Frank to also try him and comment on the credit quality. Look, and only I think, we have seen a very significant change in the underlying credit factors, right? When you think about the decrease in NPLs, the decrease in criticized assets, those are meaningful, visible and important changes. And again, results of some deliberate actions that we've taken over the past year or so. Beyond that obviously, they all contributed to, where we ended up with the reserves, but you have to keep in mind the reserve coverage only went down by 1 basis points and we've been watching our peer group over the last 2, 3 quarters, we've seen more meaningful decreases in coverage from others and ours has been relatively stable, we're actually up compared to last year's third quarter. As we look forward, clearly if there is a significant change in the way the portfolio grows that we will reflect that in the provision as we said barring any significant environmental changes we would expect provision to move overall with loan growth and that probably is a statement that others have made. Frank, any color on sort of credit environment to that?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, the -- and excuse me I've laryngitis. The work we've done really and delivered over the last 18 months to reposition the portfolio, result of that as we could have had $1 billion less in criticized assets this quarter, big number, very meaningful. We
componenttext: Ken, the -- and excuse me I've laryngitis. The work we've done really and delivered over the last 18 months to reposition the portfolio, result of that as we could have had $1 billion less in criticized assets this quarter, big number, very meaningful. We've taken about $1.4 billion off the leverage book in the last 12 months and that was a high-risk piece of the leverage book. Our commodity exposure today and the outstandings is $35 million. It's a -- it's all we have left. We're essentially out of the coal business. Our real estate exposure relative to our peers is much lower and is underwritten primarily to national and large regional developers, we believe at a very, very accretive manner. And our energy book as we've talked about before is 2% of our total book. We are looking at and maybe $60 million to $80 million of losses in energy that's over the next 8 to 9 quarters. So we've taken very deliberate actions with the work we're doing, coordinated with Lars on the commercial side to reposition this balance sheet to ensure that as we move towards the next recession, we're far better in control and in a far better position to be very successful in managing credit through the cycle. And so all of these things are, I think are pretty self-evident today. Our nonaccrual loans, again we've talked about before, it continued to come down quarter after quarter. We'll see some lumpiness like everybody does, but for the most part our outlook is very positive for 2017 relative to credit plus all the different things and the actions we've taken very deliberately with a lot of discipline in the last 18 months.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks for that color. And so the follow up to that point. You have gone to the -- it seems like more to the end of kind of cleaning up the book, cleaning out the book. And so as you pivot to future loan growth, obviously a couple of things where y
componenttext: Great, thanks for that color. And so the follow up to that point. You have gone to the -- it seems like more to the end of kind of cleaning up the book, cleaning out the book. And so as you pivot to future loan growth, obviously a couple of things where you can -- where you're clearly talking about on the consumer side. But where do you expect to then be looking to grow? I should say on the commercial side, aside from what the environment will give us, and is it a change this philosophy in terms of like how fast you want to be growing in other parts of commercial? And where do you see the commercial side growth coming from?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, I think Ken, you've touched on a good point. I mean, part of it's going to be driven by the overall economic environment and that's why we guide towards GDP. But as we continue to build out our industry verticals, those are continuin
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, I think Ken, you've touched on a good point. I mean, part of it's going to be driven by the overall economic environment and that's why we guide towards GDP. But as we continue to build out our industry verticals, those are continuing to provide nice lift for us as well as drive an excellent fee income. And frankly, attractive returns for our shareholders. We're going to continue to focus on that. We're going to continue to build that industry expertise. But I would tell you in some of our core middle market regions we've seen nice growth in North Carolina, Chicago throughout the year, South Florida, Cincinnati. So we're going to continue to focus on execution, improving that client experience, investing in new industry verticals, and frankly growing, what is a very healthy commercial real estate portfolio, where we're really seeing some nicely improved, attractive asset quality metrics, under a underwriting structure that is much different from the last cycle, centralized and in expert line of business both on the line and with risk partners.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, the only other thing I would add to Lars' comments. If you exclude the delivery exits, we would have grown the commercial book 6% to 7% in 2016. So to give you some perspective of just how much lifting we've done to reposition the book for both quali
componenttext: Ken, the only other thing I would add to Lars' comments. If you exclude the delivery exits, we would have grown the commercial book 6% to 7% in 2016. So to give you some perspective of just how much lifting we've done to reposition the book for both quality and profitability and those guys have done a fantastic job.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Pancari with Evercore.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Pancari with Evercore.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Regarding the North Star initiatives, just want to try to get a little bit more detail there, I know you just said that the amount of cost saves is about a third of the overall benefit that you expect out of the program. So of that cost-save component, ca
componenttext: Regarding the North Star initiatives, just want to try to get a little bit more detail there, I know you just said that the amount of cost saves is about a third of the overall benefit that you expect out of the program. So of that cost-save component, can you give us an idea of the timing of the recognition as you move through '17 and then '18. Just trying to get an idea how we could really start to put that in numbers. And then separately around the revenue enhancement side, assuming, obviously, that's the rest of the savings that 2/3, what type of revenue enhancement are you looking for?

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so in terms of -- how the way we look at Project North Star to give you a very broad picture. The qualification of the improvements in returns translates to a roughly $800 million type pretax income improvement between now and 2019. So the way we thi
componenttext: Yes, so in terms of -- how the way we look at Project North Star to give you a very broad picture. The qualification of the improvements in returns translates to a roughly $800 million type pretax income improvement between now and 2019. So the way we think about it is, there is a base performance uplift from the businesses that we have and in a  base case scenario, probably roughly it's about, let's call it a $3 million to $4 million. We can do that by managing the expenses and then growing the revenues that already in play. And then, we look at certain balance sheet optimization targets that we are establishing. That probably, I don't know let's call it sort of in the $100 million to $150 million range and then roughly another $150 million to $200 million in fee income growth. So that leaves somewhere around $150 million or so in expenses. These are broad numbers. We will share more details with you.  The timing of the expense saves will start coming in, in 2017, some of them are already in play, where you obviously done major restructuring. And I think it will accelerate into 2018 and '19. In some of the projects underlying expense day projects relate to the commercial business and enter and redesign that project is kicking off. It's going to have somewhat of a delayed impact, but again we would see probably a more meaningful save in 2018 and then there are other infrastructure investments that we're making. But that doesn't mean '17 does not have any of those. I think there are some expense initiatives in play that also will contribute to '17. And those are the types of details that we would like to share with you as we approach the year-end and then the beginning of the year.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we're really focused on is client relationships and building those out to the extent that we leverage the Shared National Credit market, that's more kind of just symptomatic. It is not an end for us. We're not focused on growing SNC, what we ar
componenttext: Well, what we're really focused on is client relationships and building those out to the extent that we leverage the Shared National Credit market, that's more kind of just symptomatic. It is not an end for us. We're not focused on growing SNC, what we are focused on is growing industry expertise, core middle market, where we believe that we can add value, develop deep client relationships that fit within our risk appetite and provide attractive returns.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me add a little bit to that. If you look at the SNC portfolio again which is $26 billion about 49% of our total commercial booked. It's investment grade quality. If you exclude the energy piece of SNC for a moment, we have very low loss in that. Our c
componenttext: Let me add a little bit to that. If you look at the SNC portfolio again which is $26 billion about 49% of our total commercial booked. It's investment grade quality. If you exclude the energy piece of SNC for a moment, we have very low loss in that. Our criticized asset level is 3 1/4% from the entire SNC book. It's primarily an investment-grade portfolio.  Three quarters of that portfolio is as Lars said is really deep relationships. About a quarter is credit only and a lot of those are fairly new relationships that we're building the relationship on. So this is not a stand-alone portfolio that credit-only booked that we're buying just to grow a portfolio. It's tied deeply into our strategy of dealing with relationships with top clients and I'll tell you in many of our SNC relationships, we have a very meaningful piece of the stack when you look at the number of things that are in a syndicated facility. So we feel very good about it. I don't think at the end of the day, we'll exceed 50% of our total book over time, but we don't necessarily have a problem with where it is relative to the performance that has given us,and the fact that it's built into our core strategy of deepening our industry vertical in our MidCap relationship.

headline: Fifth Third Bancorp, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
